newsitem.title: INDIA: Indian soymeal export affected by moisture content.
newsitem.headline: Indian soymeal export affected by moisture content.

text.p: Indian soymeal shipments were affected this week as buyers waited for some consignments with high moisture content to dry out before loading, traders said on Friday.
"Around 100,000 tonnes of soymeal, for November shipments, are lying at the ports," said Sunil Saboo, a leading oilmeal broker.
"Overseas buyers are waiting for the consignments to dry out before loading for shipments," said another oilmeal trader.
Traders said heavy rains during the last fortnight of November had damaged a part of the soybean crop and disrupted harvesting.
High moisture in the soymeal reduced the protein content.
Overseas buyers have asked Indian exporters to load the consignments for shipment only after the moisture content was reduced.
"But this is not a big problem and we will sort it out. We are not cancelling any contracts," said Neal Sahni, a foreign buyer, who had come to India to discuss the problems.
Traders said Indian exporters had so far signed contracts to export around 1.4 million tonnes of soymeal in 1996/97 (November-October).
Indian soymeal was currently quoted at $275 per tonne fas compared to around $218 at the same time last year.
In plant delivery conditions, soybean was quoted at around 10,300 rupees per tonne against 8,500-8,700 in the markets of central India, the hub of India's soybean processing industry.
